Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Automated Blood Flow Analysis Using Adaptive Three-Dimensional Ultrasound
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes the reduction in severe patient morbidity and elimination of hundreds of millions of dollars of expenditures by the U.S. healthcare system each year on revision surgeries and unnecessary procedures associated with late detection of post-surgical blood clots. Surgeons have the ability to prevent these catastrophic events, but only the onset of the clot can be detected in a timely manner. Currently, of the patients who form clots after the targeted surgeries, half will suffer from a surgical failure due to the shortcomings of current modalities. This technology gives clinicians the ability to non-invasively track changes in blood flow within critical vessels to enable intervention prior to any compromise in health and prevent a majority of these catastrophic incidents. Beyond significant decreases in patient suffering and morbidity, such interventions will have an enormous positive economic impact on the health care system. This technology can also substantially improve clinical understanding of the clotting process and possibly enable non-invasive therapeutic treatments for these patients who otherwise would receive surgery.

The proposed project offers significant intellectual and scientific merit associated with new methods of ultrasound flow analysis. The objective of this work is to develop a system that is able to collect a 3D volume of ultrasound data and automatically extract the blood flow data in the region of interest by detecting an implantable component. This novel approach to measuring vascular flow will be the first to enable detection of localized post-operative clot formation rather than detecting clot-related issues via delayed and indirect methods that leave patients at risk for surgical failures. This technique can allow for intervention earlier than all other available methods, thus improving patient outcomes and reducing hospital costs. Furthermore, this method enables automatic detection of critical changes in blood flow, eliminating the risk of human error. Lastly, dissemination of the technology developed in this proposal represents an important milestone towards the creation of simpler, more automated ultrasound systems that can place this non-invasive, non-ionizing modality in the hands of non-expert clinicians for use in a broader spectrum of medical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we developed algorithms for 3D ultrasound volume collection, pose recovery, and Doppler flow analysis for the ultimate purpose of detecting changes in blood flow associated with post-operative thrombosis. Software was developed to collect 3D B-mode (greyscale) ultrasound volumes, register the site via a surgically implanted marker, and perform adaptive Doppler beamforming to obtain multi-planar Doppler data which can be analyzed to determine clinical flow status. In order to verify the output from the primary effort, the process was validated in 3 ways. First, the Doppler volumetric flow algorithm accuracy was validated on a benchtop model with a flow phantom at physiologic conditions using a flowmeter. Second, we utilized a robotic system to gain precise tolerance measurements of the system in translational and rotational probe movements. By creating exact translations and rotations using a calibrated UR5 robotic arm, it was possible to determine the maximum probe motion within each degree of freedom. In order to prove true efficacy of the system, a large animal tissue transfer surgery was performed, the marker was implanted, and the software applied to measure volumetric flow. Therefore in the final task, the algorithms were further validated in a large animal model due to the added complexities associated with an in vivo surgical site. We also extended these algorithms to function for both continuous flow (veins) and pulsatile flow (arteries). 

This project offered significant scientific and clinical value associated with new methods of ultrasound flow analysis. This novel approach to measuring vascular flow is the first to enable detection of localized post-operative clot formation rather than detecting clot-related issues via delayed and indirect methods that leave patients at risk for surgical failures. The newly developed technique allows for intervention earlier than all other available methods, thus improving patient outcomes and reducing hospital costs. Lastly, the methods of Doppler data collection and analysis developed under this proposal may yield significant insight into valuable new scientific and engineering principles.

By successfully completing this work, the product will have enormous impact on reducing severe patient morbidity in addition to eliminating hundreds of millions of dollars of expenditures by the U.S. healthcare system each year on revision surgeries and unnecessary procedures. If clinicians were to have the ability to track changes in flow within blood vessels non-invasively surgeons could intervene prior to the onset of any compromise in health and prevent a majority of these catastrophic incidents. Beyond the patient suffering and morbidity, such an intervention has an enormous positive impact on healthcare economics.
